Award.AbstractNarration:
Status hierarchies are a part of our everyday social interactions, and those with higher status have numerous advantages, including access to resources and improved health. A key area of research within social and personality psychology is to understand how status hierarchies are formed and maintained. Who attains higher status positions within their groups (e.g., leadership positions), and how? Because higher status in social hierarchies confers benefits compared to lower status, answers to these questions have fundamental implications for explaining disparities in outcomes such as hiring, pay, and health. Traditional biosocial theories of status propose that elevated testosterone concentrations should lead to higher status by enhancing dominant behaviors (e.g., confidence, assertiveness), but evidence in support of these theories is inconsistent. Recently Pranjal Mehta (University of Oregon) and his colleagues have proposed that testosterone may interact with contextual factors and other hormones to regulate behaviors implicated in the pursuit of social status. Building on this dual-systems approach, the proposed research investigates the extent to which testosterone's influence on social status depends on cortisol, a hormone released during periods of physical and psychological stress. This research will generate novel insights into the fundamental biosocial mechanisms of social status. These studies have numerous implications for designing psychological interventions aimed at improving professional and health outcomes among lower status, marginalized individuals and groups.

According to the dual-hormone hypothesis, testosterone should enhance social status only when cortisol is low. The proposed research will test the novel hypothesis that testosterone and cortisol should jointly strategically motivate behaviors that improve one's status depending on the social context, through both dominance and pro-social behaviors (e.g., friendliness, generosity). The proposed research will test this biosocial mechanism of status attainment in a mock job interview setting, group-based social interactions, and real-world status hierarchies. The studies integrate cutting-edge methodologies within social-personality psychology and behavioral neuroendocrinology to address the research aims, including hormone administration, endogenous hormone measurement, experimental manipulations of social context, and behavioral observation. The research examines both baseline hormone concentrations as well as context-driven hormone fluctuations over time in order to understand how endocrine systems dynamically influence and are influenced by status-seeking behaviors and social status.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Status hierarchies are a part of our everyday social interactions, and those with higher status have numerous advantages, including access to resources and improved health. A key area of research within social and personality psychology is to understand how status hierarchies are formed and maintained. Who attains higher status positions within their groups (e.g., leadership positions), and how? Because higher status in social hierarchies confers benefits compared to lower status, answers to these questions have fundamental implications for explaining disparities in outcomes such as hiring, pay, and health.

Traditional biosocial theories of status propose that elevated testosterone concentrations should lead to higher status, but evidence in support of these theories is inconsistent. An alternative perspective is that testosterone may interact cortisol, a hormone released during periods of physical and psychological stress, to regulate status-seeking behaviors. Building on this dual-systems approach, this research investigated the extent to which testosterone's influence on status depends on cortisol and features of the social context.

The current project tested this biosocial theory of status attainment in dyadic settings, group-based social interactions, and real-world status hierarchies. The studies integrated methodologies within social-personality psychology and behavioral neuroendocrinology to address the research aims, including hormone administration, endogenous hormone measurement, experimental manipulations of social context, and behavioral observation. The research examined both baseline hormone concentrations as well as context-driven hormone fluctuations in order to understand how endocrine systems dynamically influence and are influenced by status-seeking behaviors and social status.

The results suggest higher testosterone was related to higher status only when cortisol levels were low but not when cortisol levels were high. Additional evidence suggests that high-testosterone low-cortisol individuals may attain high status because they selectively choose to enter competitions against high-status but not low-status opponents, which may increase their opportunities to ascend the social hierarchy. By contrast, high-testosterone high-cortisol individuals actively avoid competition against high-status opponents, which may explain why they fail to attain high-status positions.

These results suggest that testosterone and cortisol levels affect status-seeking behaviors and status attainment, but additional results provide evidence for the reverse causal pathway. Attainment of high status caused acute changes in testosterone and cortisol levels, and these hormone changes in turn predicted status-seeking behaviors. Collectively, the findings suggest that hormones and status influence each other in reciprocal feedback loops. These bidirectional causal pathways linking testosterone and cortisol to status were found in both men and women.

The results raise important directions for future research on the social neuroendocrinology of status. First, hormonal influences on status-relevant behaviour sometimes depended on two self-reported personality traits: dominance and impulsivity. Future research is required to understand the mechanisms and boundary conditions for these effects. Second, the results suggest that the standard hormone measurement technique in the field of social neuroendocrinology (immunoassay) may not be sufficiently accurate when levels of a hormone are very low (e.g. salivary testosterone, particularly in women). Future research should build on the present results by adopting more accurate techniques for hormone measurement, such as mass spectrometry. Finally, the project focused on testosterone, cortisol, and status. Future work is needed to understand effects of other hormones, such as estradiol (an estrogen hormone) and progesterone, in status hierarchies.

This project facilitated the training of several undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, many of whom were from underrepresented groups (e.g. women and members of ethnic minority groups). This project also facilitated collaboration between academia and industry, which enabled the research team to collect data in naturalistic settings and share findings with practitioners in real-world organisations. This project focused on the fundamental biosocial processes that regulate status, but the findings have implications for designing psychological interventions aimed at improving professional and health outcomes among lower status, marginalized individuals and groups.
